notes: Perfect match on assay comparison claims (C77-C83). Both agree that seqspec successfully demonstrates comparison of SPLiT-seq, SHARE-seq, and sci-CAR-seq structures with valid scientific content.

Perfect match on scope/utility claims (C65-C67, C88-C89). LLM finds these speculative without demonstrated evidence, while peer reviewers implicitly accept these claims about reprocessing utility and batch effect identification without challenge.

Perfect match on future extension claims (C72-C73, C75-C76, C84, C87). Both agree these are speculative. LLM notes they are aspirational goals; peer reviewers raise concerns about versioning and backwards compatibility, indicating uncertainty about future extensibility.

High overlap (75% Jaccard) on preprocessing integration (C62-C64). Both agree the demonstration with kallisto bustools, simpleaf/alevin-fry, and STARsolo is valid and the tool works as described. LLM R3 includes C85 not in peer R5.

Moderate overlap (54.5% Jaccard) on standardization/utility claims (C4-C5, C69-C71, C86). LLM finds claims about facilitating standardization inferential with limited empirical evidence, while peer reviewers explicitly support the tool's value for standardization and communication.

Moderate overlap (44.7% Jaccard) on technical design claims (C31-C47). Both agree the Region-based annotation system, YAML format, and nested structure are well-designed and technically sound. LLM R1 includes additional claims not in peer R3.

Moderate overlap (42.3% Jaccard) on background/technical foundation claims (C12-C22). Both agree on the characterization of sequencing library structure, technologies, and assay complexity as established knowledge.
Moderate overlap (37.5% Jaccard) on motivation claims (C1-C2, C7-C11, C23-C24). Both agree the problem statement and need for standardization are well-established and valid.
Moderate overlap (36.8% Jaccard) on command-line tool claims (C48-C61). Both agree the seqspec CLI and its eleven subcommands are functional and well-implemented.
Low overlap (16.7% Jaccard) on prior work claims (C25-C28). Both agree on characterization of Chen 2020 database limitations and the need for machine-readable formats.

Minimal overlap (9.1% Jaccard) on innovation claim (C68). LLM finds comparative claims about innovating beyond kb-python/simpleaf lack rigorous benchmarking, while peer reviewers accept the tool's value without questioning this specific comparison.
Minimal overlap (7.1% Jaccard) on preprocessing demonstration (C85). Both agree on the successful implementation of preprocessing tool integration.
Minimal overlap (6.5% Jaccard) on core specification claims (C3, C29-C30). Both agree the seqspec specification is well-defined and represents a valuable contribution.
Minimal overlap (4.1% Jaccard) on technical background (C90-C91). Both agree on foundational technical descriptions of sequencing technologies and assays.

Minimal overlap (2.6% Jaccard) on initial release claim (C74). Both confirm availability of specification collection, though peer reviewer notes 38 vs manuscript's 49 assays (likely timing difference).

Minimal overlap (2.6% Jaccard) on availability claim (C6). LLM finds tool availability well-documented, while peer reviewers express uncertainty about publication-ready release standards (GitHub size, formatting issues, need for PyPI/Bioconda distribution).
